div.p: We will begin with Module 1,

Achieving High Performance
in Federal Buildings.
A sustainable strategy can be evaluated
using a triple bottom line framework.
The three components in this framework

are environmental stewardship,
social responsibility,
and economic prosperity.

Successful sustainable
strategies incorporate all three.

Environment stewardship consists
of protecting air, water,

land, and ecosystems as
well as conserving resources
including fossil fuels.

Social responsibility involves
improving the quality of life
and equity for individuals, communities,
and society as a whole.

Finally, economic prosperity
involves reducing costs,

adding value, and creating
economic opportunities

for individuals, organizations,
communities, and nations.
While there are many facets

to a strategic sustainability
performance plan,

this course will focus
on four fundamentals;
optimizing energy performance,
protection and conservation of water,

use of environmentally preferable
products and materials,
and enhanced indoor environmental quality.

The first fundamental of
sustainable facility management
is the optimization of energy performance.

Supplies of fossil fuel are
increasingly unreliable,

concerns for energy
security are on the rise,
and the impacts of global climate change
are becoming more evident.
Sustainable and high-performance buildings
are critical to reduce energy load,
increase resource efficiency,

and maximize cost-effective
renewable energy technologies.

Federal agencies are
increasingly committed
to significantly reducing
our dependence on foreign energy sources
and energy derived from fossil fuels.
Optimizing energy performance begins

by reducing energy consumption
and associated costs,

increasing resource efficiency,
and maximizing the use
of cost-effective renewable technologies.

It is important to measure and
verify energy use frequently

in order to properly track
performance over time.
This fundamental practice is in line
with a federal commitment put forward
in the Greening Government Strategy
stating that the government of Canada

will reduce scope one and scope
two greenhouse gas emissions
from federal facilities and fleets
by 80% below 2005 levels by 2050.

There are many benefits that
can result from taking action
on optimizing energy performance.

The environmental benefits
are lower electricity

and fossil fuel use, lower
greenhouse gas emissions,
and associated air pollution

caused by fossil fuel
production and distribution.
The economic benefits,

such as lower first
costs and operating costs
when systems can be downsized
due to integrated energy solutions;
reduced dependence on imported oil;
lower annual fuel and electricity costs;

reduced peak power demand;
and cost and reduced need
for new energy infrastructure.
The protection and conservation of water

is another fundamental of
sustainable facility management.

Although 2/3 of the
Earth's surface is water,

less than 1/2 of 1% is
available for our use.

By creating a strategic
sustainability plan
that uses water wisely, we can reduce use

and its associated energy
and environmental impacts.
Much like energy,

water use should be measured
and verified frequently

to track improvements over
time and identify leaks.

The federal government is
committed to the protection

and conservation of water
and has stated the following
in the Greening Government Strategy.

The government of Canada will
reduce its water consumption

by tracking and disclosing
its potable water consumption

by 2022 using best in
class water use practices

in new construction and
major renovations and in
designing all new Crown-owned buildings
to effectively manage storm water.

The environmental
benefits of taking action

on preserving water include
lower potable water consumption

and pollution discharge into
our aquifers and waterways,
the preservation of water resources
for wildlife and agriculture,
and the restoration of wetland ecologies.

The economic benefits of
protecting and conserving water
include reduced annual water costs,

lower municipal costs
for wastewater treatment,

and lower first costs
for certain fixtures.

A sustainable building is
constructed of materials

that minimize life cycle
environmental impacts

such as global climate
change, resource depletion,
and human toxicity.
Environmentally preferable materials

reduce waste and disposal
costs, preserve the environment,

and contribute to employee
health and safety.

Sustainable materials
minimize life cycle costs
and reduce waste.

They protect the health
and safety of the tenants

and they decrease the
need for fossil fuels.

The government of Canada
is committed to reducing

the environmental impact
of building materials
using life-cycle assessment techniques

to minimize embodied carbon and
the use of harmful materials
in construction and renovation.

The environmental benefits
are reducing mining
and harvesting of virgin resources;

reduced strain on
ecosystems from disposal;
and reduced energy use from material

and resource transportation,
manufacturing, and processing.

The economic benefits
are decreased first costs

due to local material
harvesting, material reuse,
and use of recycled materials;

lower costs for treatment
and waste disposal;
and lower municipal costs for construction
and operation of landfills.

Another fundamental of
sustainable facility management
is enhancing indoor environmental quality.
Sustainable facility management

avoids the use of harmful
chemicals and materials,
aims to improve air quality
and create productive environments,

and facilitates interactivity
among building occupants.
Even a small boost to worker productivity
can result in savings
that can offset the costs of improvements.
As part of its Greening strategy,

the government of Canada
will focus on the well-being

of its employees and
communities in which it operates
by creating sustainable workplaces

and mobilizing employees
on government greening.
The environmental benefits

related to improved indoor
environmental quality

include better air quality
inside the facility,
reduced volatile organic emissions,

and reduced carbon dioxide
and carbon monoxide emission.

The economic benefits of
enhanced environmental quality

are healthier and more
productive work environments,
higher organizational productivity,

lower absenteeism, and
reduced staff turnover,
and disability/health insurance costs.

Energy and facility managers
control more resources
that potentially impact sustainability
than most other professionals on site.

In the short term they
establish baselines,

initiate projects, facilitate
discussions with coworkers,

and identify opportunities for
teamwork and collaboration.

In the long-term they have the
potential to create momentum
and keep progress and focus
as ongoing sustainability projects evolve.

Through their leadership, a
tremendous change in energy
and environmental quality is possible.
Sustainability is a cyclical process
for continuous improvement
and still requires a continuous effort.
It should not be viewed as an end game
with a finish line to cross.

Do whatever you can with
the resources at hand,
set a goal to move beyond compliance,
and then improve upon your own benchmarks
as you work toward those goals.

Even if you can't meet
the goals of this year,
how close can you get?

Can you set your sights higher
and continually reevaluate
and improve your process?
Always be in a listening mode
to continually evaluate and look for new
or enhanced sustainable measures to apply.
Because individuals determine
how buildings are used and maintained,
sustainability initiatives must recognize
the critical connection between buildings
and the people who use them.

Organizing a sustainable
facility team or green team
is a proven way to engage individuals

with varying responsibilities
and perspectives
who share a stake in facility operations.
A green team can be formal or informal
but should always be multidisciplinary.
In Module 1,

we covered the triple bottom
line of sustainability,

the importance of leadership
in the federal sector,

the four fundamentals of
sustainable facility management,

integrating the four fundamentals
into a holistic plan,

and the leadership role of
the energy/facility manager
in the team process.
In the next module,

we will cover ways to
identify the best strategies

to implement sustainable
measures at your site.
